msDesc.head: Wulfstan, Canons of Edgar and Institutes of Polity (fragments)

msContents.summary: A fragment of two adjacent leaves, containing part of 'Institutes of Polity', the same text as fols 22v/8-26/13 of Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Junius 121. Some lines are missing on each leaf and letters are missing from the inner margin of the second leaf. Possibly from South-West England.

msItem.author: Wulfstan, Archbishop of York (d. 1023)
msItem.title: Institutes of Polity, 19 (partial)-20
msItem.incipit: 1: godes mihta þam sacerdum fylstað sƿa oft sƿa hi criste þeniað mid rihte
msItem.explicit: 2: Lærað cristene folc georne ˥ lacniað hit georne
msItem.note: Text begins imperfectly and concludes at the end of Polity 20.
msItem.filiation:
See also:
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 201
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 421
London, British Library, Cotton MS Nero A.i, fols B. xi, ff. 70-177
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Junius 121

msItem.author: Wulfstan, Archbishop of York (d. 1023)
msItem.title: Canons of Edgar: Of Penitents, 4-9
msItem.incipit: 2: And ge þencað þæt se læce þe sceal yfele ƿunda hælan. he mot habban gode sealfeto.
msItem.explicit: 2: ealsƿa on godum læce byð þearflic broces bot ˥ Bemannes geƿyrhte hit man mot æfter canondome ˥ eac meo
msItem.filiation:
See also:
Brussels, Bibliothèque Royale, MS 8558-62 (2498)
Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.1.33
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 201
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 265
London, British Library, Cotton MS Tiberius A.iii
London, British Library, Cotton MS Claudius A.iii
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Junius 121
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Laud Misc. 482

msItem.author: Wulfstan, Archbishop of York, (d. 1023)
msItem.title: Institutes of Polity, 21
msItem.incipit: 3: Tæcað cristenum mannum georne and gelome rihtne geleafan ˥ þæt hi cunnon heora cristendomes gescead . ˥ þæt hi heora fulluhtes gescead ƿitan.
msItem.explicit: 3: ge on eallum godum dædum dreogan his ƿillan. þonne magon ƿe egðer. ge ús sylfum ƿel fremian. ge eallum cristenum mannum.
msItem.filiation:
See also:
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 201
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 421
London, British Library, Cotton MS Nero A.i, fols B. xi, fols 70-177
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Junius 121

msItem.author: Wulfstan, Archbishop of York (d. 1023)
msItem.title: Institutes of Polity, 21-22
msItem.incipit: 3: Leofan men doð sƿa ic eoƿ lære for godes lufan ˥ for
msItem.explicit: 4: sƿa geƿissian moton sƿa sƿa ura ealra þearf sy
msItem.note: Line of text partially cropped at the foot of 3, and further text lost before its resumption on 4.
msItem.filiation:
See also
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 201
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 421
London, British Library, MS Nero A.i, fols B. xi, fols 70-177
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Junius 121

msItem.author: Wulfstan, Archbishop of York (d. 1023)
msItem.title: Canons of Edgar: 1-8
msItem.incipit: 4: Riht is þæt preostas beon geornlice gode þeoƿiende ˥ þeniende ˥ for eal cristen folc þingiende ˥ þæt hiealle beon
msItem.explicit: 4: ˥ sibbian heora agene geferan oþþe sceotan to þam bisceope gif man nyde scyle. ˥ riht is þæt ænig
msItem.filiation:
See also
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 201
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Junius 121

foliation.note: The fragment has not been foliated.

collation.note: Some lines are missing on each leaf and some letters are missing from the inner margin of the second leaf. Approximately five lines are missing from the top of the first leaf and three lines from the top of the second leaf.

condition.note: The surface of the parchment is damaged from the glue used when the leaf was reused as a pastedown in a binding and there are also some holes.

layout.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, most visible in the lower right-hand corner of the first page.

handNote.p: English vernacular minuscule. According to N.R. Ker, 'a neat, rather pointed hand: 'e' round-backed: long and low forms of 's' used indifferently: long ascenders and descenders: the ends of the descenders are usually seriffed.' The aspect is broad but pointed and slightly backward-leaning. Rustic capitals are used at the beginning of sections.
Summary of the characteristics of the hand (from Takako Kato):

list.item: Insular single compartment a is triangular, but rounded.
The a component of æ is rounded triangular, and the same height as or slightly higher than e.
Insular d is round-backed, with the short upstroke at 45º, and tapering backward to the right.
e is round and its horizontal line goes up to the right and often finishes with a tongue.

Insular f: the downstroke is straight with a wedged top and finishes with a serif that turns up to the right, and the tongue is longer than the shoulder. The shoulder consists of a upright diagonal and a short downward vertical line.
Insular g has a flat top; the vertical stroke joins the horizontal bar towards the left, and the lower lobe is closed. The sizes of the upper and lower lobes are the same.
Insular h: the ascender has a split top; both limbs are straight and have distinct serifs that turn up to the right at 45º.
minims have distinct serifs that turn up to the right at 45º.
r is insular.

There are two kinds of s: insular s with a straight descender with a serif to the right, and a long s with a descender which descends slightly below the writing line. The descender of long s tapers slightly to the left at the end.
t is round-backed and its head-stroke is horizontal. The back-stroke joins the head-stroke at the left side.
The ascender of ð is tall at 45º and tapers slightly backward to the right. The prominent cross-bar has an upward serif to the right at its left end, and downward serif to the left at its right end.
The ascender of þ is wedged or has a split, and its descender is short and has a serif to the right.
The descender of ƿ is straight and finishes with an upward serif to the right.
y is dotted and the first stroke is thick, whereas the second stroke is a thin line with a wedge of a split at the top, and its descender finishes with a upward serif to the right.
ascenders are often split or wedged at the top (see b, l, þ).
descenders: straight descenders are as long as the height of the body, or sometimes shorter, and often finish with distinct serifs that turn up to the right at 45º. (See insular low r, low s, ƿ).
the cross-bar of þæt has an upward serif to the right at its left-hand end, and a downward serif to the left at its right-hand end.
macron has an upward serif to the right at its left-hand end, and a downward serif to the left at its right-hand end.
the descender of ˥ is straight and usually has a serif to the right at the end. Its head slightly curves inwards. Sometimes a larger ˥ is used at the beginning of sentences.

decoNote.p: There is a three-line initial in red on 4 at the beginning of the Canons of Edgar ('R' in 'Riht').
Some initial capital letters are black and coloured with red.

binding.p: The fragment is currently kept in a loose black cover, together with notes by Felix Liebermann Liebermann, F. (Felix), 1851-1925 and N.R. Ker Ker, N.R. (Neil Ripley) (the latter dated May 1938).

accMat.p: A fragment of a printed book, which was probably also used for the binding, is attached to the second leaf (pp. 3-4). Some letters of the printed fragment are visible on the right-hand side of p. 3.
A note in the handwriting of Felix Liebermann, which explains the contents of the leaves, is kept with the fragments.

Another note signed by 'The Librarian University Library' (i.e. Francis Jenkinson Jenkinson, Francis, 1853-1923 ) contains information about the most recent sale: 'Add. 3206 Saxon Homilies. Ab. 1050 two leaves. 1893. Sotheby's Bateman Sale lot. 1528'.

history.origin:
Second half of the 11th century, England.
The palaeography suggests possibly South-West England.

provenance.p: The leaves were pastedowns in the binding of a book of octavo size. Formerly part of Cambridge University Library, MS Add. 4166, a collection of fragments bought by Samuel Sandars Sandars, S. (Samuel) in the Bateman sale at Sotheby's, 25 May 1893, lot 1528.

history.acquisition: Bequeathed to Cambridge University by Sandars in 1894.

recordHist.source: This record draws on N.R. Ker, Catalogue of manuscripts containing Anglo-Saxon (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1990 reissue) and Takako Kato's description of the manuscript at The Production and Use of English Manuscripts 1060 to 1220 (2010-13).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: Ancient laws and institutes of England: comprising laws enacted under the Anglo-Saxon kings from Aethelbirht to Cnut, with an English translation of the Saxon; the laws called Edward the Confessor's; the laws of William the Conqueror, and those ascribed to Henry the First; also, Monumenta ecclesiastica Anglicana, from the seventh to the tenth century; and the ancient Latin version of the Anglo-Saxon laws; with a ... glossary etc
Ancient laws and institutes of England
Die "Institutes of polity, civil and ecclesiastical": Ein Werk Erzbischof Wulfstans von York
Die "Institutes of polity, civil and ecclesiastical."
